photo.description: Completed 112 AD, the column 113 AD this is the youngest of the Fora of Rome, build with and commemorating respectively Trajan's victories in Dacia (Romania). Trajan's Column has, of course, been capped by another dumb Christian monument.

photo.description: Brick core with a veneer, once part of Trajan's Forum. Sides of the Quirinal and Capitoline hills of Rome were excavated in order to build the forum (making our walk steeper than it might have been in the first century).

photo.description: On our way to Tazza d'Oro for granitas. Designed as the centerpiece to Trajan's Forum in 113 CE by Apollodorus of Damascus, a Greek architect from Syria. Fitting, since Trajan himself was born in Spain, the first non-Italian Emperor. Under him, the Roman Empire expanded to its greatest size; the spiraling bas relief on the column commemorates Trajan's victories in the Dacian Wars. The column stands 125 feet including its base, and was once topped by a gilded bronze statue of the Emperor himself. This statue was destroyed sometime in the Middle Ages, and in 1588 Pope Sixtus V replaced it with the statue of Saint Peter that remains there today. See where this picture was taken. [?]

photo.description: We ended up wandering back to Trajan's Forum, aiming for a Metro line back to the hotel, carrying some supplies picked up from an accidentally discovered eSpar. Meant I could get some more shots of his column, which I was pleased about. Meant we were getting more and more worn out, which we weren't.
photo.title: Trajan's Column

photo.description: Family holiday in Rome, Summer 2006. This is the Victor Emmanuel II Monument. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II_monument View from the VEII monument of other buildings and a column with statue. Building with a dome. View includes: Church of the Most Holy Name of Mary and Trajan's Column. Santissimo Nome di Maria al Foro Traiano The Church of the Most Holy Name of Mary at the Trajan Forum (Italian: Santissimo Nome di Maria al Foro Traiano, Latin: Ss. Nominis Mariae ad forum Traiani) is a Roman Catholic church in Rome. This church should not be confused with the church Santissimo Nome di Maria in Via Latina in south-east Rome. The feast of the Holy Name of Mary was instituted by Pope Innocent XI after the victory of the Austrian-Polish armies under the command of John III Sobieski over the Turks at the Battle of Vienna in 1683. Abbot Giuseppe Bianchi instituted devotion to the most holy name of Mary in 1685 at Santo Stefano del Cacco, and soon afterwards established the Congregation of the Most Holy Name of Mary, which was formally approved in 1688. Trajan's Column Trajan's Column (Italian: Colonna Traiana) is a Roman triumphal column in Rome, Italy, which commemorates Roman emperor Trajan's victory in the Dacian Wars. It was probably constructed under the supervision of the architect Apollodorus of Damascus at the order of the Roman Senate. It is located in Trajan's Forum, built near the Quirinal Hill, north of the Roman Forum. Completed in 113 CE, the freestanding column is most famous for its spiral bas relief, that artistically describes the epic wars between the Romans and Dacians (101–102 and 105–106). Its design has inspired numerous victory columns, both ancient and modern. The structure is about 30 metres (98 ft) in height, 35 metres (125 ft) including its large pedestal. The shaft is made from a series of 20 colossal Carrara marble drums, each weighing about 32 tons, with a diameter of 3.7 metres (11 ft). The 190-metre (625 ft) frieze winds around the shaft 23 times. Inside the shaft, a spiral staircase of 185 stairs provides access to a viewing platform at the top. The capital block of Trajan's Column weighs 53.3 tons, which had to be lifted to a height of c. 34 m. Ancient coins indicate preliminary plans to top the column with a statue of a bird, probably an eagle, but after construction a statue of Trajan was put in place; this statue disappeared in the Middle Ages. On December 4, 1587, the top was crowned by Pope Sixtus V with a bronze figure of St. Peter, which remains to this day.

photo.description: JSOVT(MB), the Italian edition. These are the stairs up to the Palazzo Senatorio on the Piazza del Campidoglio, where we rested for a few minutes to figure out where to go next – or was it how to get back to the hotel? Probably the latter, because on this day, we had already seen the Palatin, the Colosseum, Forum Romanum, Trajan's Column, and had been up on the Monumento nazionale a Vittorio Emanuele II, so we were pretty well worn out...

photo.description: I was so wowed by the ruins and history of the area that I just kept snapping pictures. To someone who'd lived in America her whole life, to see something from 2,000 years ago was mind-blowing.
photo.tags: ruins architecture film filmphoto italy lazio rome trajansforum italia roma
photo.title: Trajan's Forum

photo.description: This was the first place we went to when we came to Rome (after going to our hotel). It was around 9 A.M., and we'd just flown into Rome. I hadn't slept on the 12 hour flight at all, and my ears hadn't totally popped since the plane wasn't properly depressurized. Needless to say, the fact that I was able to take decent photos and remember anything is pretty impressive.
photo.tags: ruins architecture film filmphoto italy lazio rome trajansforum italia roma
photo.title: Trajan's Forum
